image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Study Area –North eastern sector of the OML 123 acreage; part of a fault block system along the Nigeria-Cameroon border (red rectangle). Ref: www.proactiveinvestors.com

formatted-caption.caption-text: Study Area –North eastern sector of the OML 123 acreage; part of a fault block system along the Nigeria-Cameroon border (red rectangle). Ref: www.proactiveinvestors.com

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Biafra Member (Figure-2) which includes all reservoirs from P-4 to I-4 is a deltaic sequence made-up of numerous stacked, upward-coarsening units, with prodelta shales and silts near the base, grading upwards into medium- to coarse-grained upper-delta and shallow-marine sandstones at the top. The reservoir sandstones of the Biafra Member were deposited in a high-energy, wave-dominated deltaic environment, prograding over the thick prodelta shales of the Akata Formation. The Akata Formation is the main hydrocarbon source rock for the overlying Biafra reservoir sands.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Biafra Member in the Stratigraphy of the Study Area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Biafra Member in the Stratigraphy of the Study Area

linkTarget.anchoringText: The interpre-tation of the petrophysical logs is refined by integration of rock physics knowledge to define the impact of clays distribution contributing to the low resistivity effect with confirmation of dispersed clay content. Rock typing and structure characterization is improved by the detailed investigation of NMR signal distribution compared to features revealed by borehole images data at highest resolution. Finally, the results of extensive core data analysis is made available and added to the evaluation workflow (Figure-3) to validate the parameters and verify the rock properties at different scale.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Flow chart of the analytic logs-based integrated to cores procedure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flow chart of the analytic logs-based integrated to cores procedure

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several intervals prone to develop into LRLC sand reservoirs have also been identified during drilling; however routine logs data acquisition is basic and insufficient to delineate and quantify to any extent this LRLC sand. To confirm the existence of a reservoir system and producible hydrocarbon, a recent well was designed to target the evaluation of the potential LRLC layers. Detailed interpretation of borehole image logs with dips and texture with core snaps (Figure-4) suggested the reservoir interval to have been deposited around the pro-delta (Figure-5) in a shallow marine environment with low energy of deposition.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Image log facies with corresponding core snaps

formatted-caption.caption-text: Image log facies with corresponding core snaps

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several intervals prone to develop into LRLC sand reservoirs have also been identified during drilling; however routine logs data acquisition is basic and insufficient to delineate and quantify to any extent this LRLC sand. To confirm the existence of a reservoir system and producible hydrocarbon, a recent well was designed to target the evaluation of the potential LRLC layers. Detailed interpretation of borehole image logs with dips and texture with core snaps (Figure-4) suggested the reservoir interval to have been deposited around the pro-delta (Figure-5) in a shallow marine environment with low energy of deposition.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Inferred depositional environment for the LRLC intervals, with borehole image logs and Core

formatted-caption.caption-text: Inferred depositional environment for the LRLC intervals, with borehole image logs and Core

linkTarget.anchoringText: Remapping these intervals using modern petrophysical techniques linked to geology from images and cores have significant production and reserve implications as pictured in the study. Log responses are studied on high level of detail to derive rock quality, fluids content, and their ability to move. The main petrophysical outputs over the zone of interested are summarized in the Figure-6 (image compressed at 1:100).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Main petrophysical logs summary and rock quality analysis describing the heterogeneity of the rock, and presence of dispersed clays within the fine grained sand and laminated component in shale. Average aspect ratios of sand and shale beds in combination with innovative multi-component modeling are deployed and coupled to expert multi-frequency magnetic resonance for quantitative estimation of hydrocarbon potential. NMR separates signals from gas, oil and water unambiguously and quantify the correct height of the oil column independently from the dual-water saturation-resistivity equations

formatted-caption.caption-text: Main petrophysical logs summary and rock quality analysis describing the heterogeneity of the rock, and presence of dispersed clays within the fine grained sand and laminated component in shale. Average aspect ratios of sand and shale beds in combination with innovative multi-component modeling are deployed and coupled to expert multi-frequency magnetic resonance for quantitative estimation of hydrocarbon potential. NMR separates signals from gas, oil and water unambiguously and quantify the correct height of the oil column independently from the dual-water saturation-resistivity equations

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure-7 shows the petrophysical analysis with available core measurements for the well and reservoir of interest in the study area (logs image compressed at 1:100).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Core data integrated to petrophysical logs results. Spectral analysis of Thorium, Uranium, and Potassium from cores (Track 1) is added to the petrophysical evaluation for complete clays analysis; there is a good agreement between the total porosity from cores and the NMR fluid corrected porosity as well as porosity from matrix corrected neutron-density logs (Track 4). The fluids saturation from logs is also validated by core data analysis (Track 7) as well as the fluid ability to move depicted by advanced NMR study with refined cutoffs (Track 8). Core pictures: fine sandy heterolith with mud/organic (a), fine grained, silty sandstone (b), massive well sorted fine grained sandstone with better porosity (c), very fine silty sandstone mixed with muddy heterolith predominant at the base (d)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core data integrated to petrophysical logs results. Spectral analysis of Thorium, Uranium, and Potassium from cores (Track 1) is added to the petrophysical evaluation for complete clays analysis; there is a good agreement between the total porosity from cores and the NMR fluid corrected porosity as well as porosity from matrix corrected neutron-density logs (Track 4). The fluids saturation from logs is also validated by core data analysis (Track 7) as well as the fluid ability to move depicted by advanced NMR study with refined cutoffs (Track 8). Core pictures: fine sandy heterolith with mud/organic (a), fine grained, silty sandstone (b), massive well sorted fine grained sandstone with better porosity (c), very fine silty sandstone mixed with muddy heterolith predominant at the base (d)
